segments.text: This is an interview with John Parrish by Von Pig on November 26, 1988 at John's apartment concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is this okay with you?
That's fine with me.
All right.
John, could you please tell me when you were born?
I was born May 14, 1949.
Okay, and where?
I was born in Mineral Wells, Texas.
Could you also please tell me...
I went through school, finished high school, got 12 hours of college.
That's about it.
Okay.
When did you join the Army, John?
1967, December.
Why'd you join?
Well, at the time, in the neighborhood that we grew up in, that's what everybody had to do, more or less.
Everybody went in before you, and it was just a thing to do, and they just won't get you sooner or later.
So you weren't drafted.
This wasn't voluntary?
I volunteered for the draft.
Volunteered for the draft.
Could you give me a brief sketch about your military career before you went to Vietnam?
Okay, but I went in December of 1967.
They sent me to Fort Polk, Louisiana for boot camp.
From there I stayed at Fort Polk for another eight weeks of AIT.
And from there they sent me to Germany.
I was there in Germany for approximately five, six months where I reenlisted three years to leave Germany to go to Vietnam.
And then from Germany, after reenlisting, I went to Vietnam.
All right.
Where were you stationed in Vietnam?
I was stationed on the Delta for seven, eight months in a small town called Ben Thuy.
And the last year and a half, I served just outside of Pleiku in the Central Highlands.
What units were you stationed with, first at Ventui and then up at... At Ventui, I think I was with the 34th Engineers.
And then when I went north to the Central Highlands to be with my brother, my twin brother, that was the B Battery 1st and 92nd Artillery.
And this artillery unit was stationed close to Pleiku up in the Central Highlands area, right?
Yeah, so the unit B battery was located out in the field on a fire sport base.
Our base camp was Pleiku.
What was your rank during your tenure at Vietnam?
Well, I finished as an E-5, and the time I was up there, field grade.
It went so fast.
As soon as I got up to Central Highlands, I was a spec four.
And no time at all, I was an E-5.
How long were you in Vietnam?
Two years.
Two years.
Did you volunteer for a second tour during that time?
I volunteered twice.
I volunteered a third time, but it was turned down.
Turned down.
And what was your MOS?
I finished up as a 13 Echo 20 as a recon sergeant.
John, could you please describe the job of your unit and what they were there for?
The B Battery was mainly for support in that region.
We were located in a very high hilltop and it was mainly for support for any units or any other bases that was around us.
It was mainly for support, fire support, artillery support.
So y'all would be called upon by units in the field for artillery support any time?
Were you called on by the American Army or the South Vietnamese Army or both?
In our region, there was no American infantry.
The region we was in was all Vietnamese.
We had some Korean soldiers.
We were called the Rocks.
And we had mountain yards.
It was led by the Special Forces units.
All right.
Why don't you describe your job to me and what you did?
Okay.
My main job, and this is when I went to the Central Highlands, was when I first started out, my MOS did not include artillery.
I never had artillery training whatsoever.
And I left the Delta to be with my twin brother.
He was mainly artilleryman.
And I wanted to be up there with them, and I finally got the approval to go to be with him.
So we was together, and I basically started out being a journeyman, OJT training.
And I started out just breaking open powder canisters for the 155 pouch.
That's how I started out.
And I winded up being a board observer.
All right, could you describe what you would do as a forward observer?
As a forward observer, we'd go out, we'd try to find out what unit or what job, what specific job you would have to do.
It could be anywhere from going out with an RV division, a mountain yard division, or a company.
They had four companies called Mike Strike Units, or you could have been on a convoy unit.
And your job as an FO, if you were an FO, an FO was to call in artillery fire.
An RTO, which I was an RTO also, you had to start out as an RTO, then an FO.
An RTO was a radio operator.
You carried the radio.
So I did all those things.
All right.
Describe a daily routine that you would follow
at your base camp or if you were out as a former observer?
Well, let's see.
I'm trying to see which way to go with this.
I played two parts.
I guess I can go ahead and say or talk about mainly our life on the fire support base because that was home.
If you wasn't out there in the bush as an FO or a G.O., you was up here on this fire support base.
This fire support base was located in a high mountain ridge, and the only way to get up there was by helicopter.
And that's where you lived, and you lived in what we called hooches.
And you dug holes into the mountain, filled sandbags, and you protected it with sandbags and also some metal pieces if you were lucky to find them.
And then in order to keep you dry, if you were lucky, you got elephant hide.
You lived up there in this little fire base.
Your main job was to mainly give support.
If everything was quiet, mainly you kept the guns clean.
You kept them swabbed down.
You cleaned out the breaches.
You made sure that everything was in working order.
How long were you up on this fire base?
On the fire base, just off and on, I was up there a year and a half.
A year and a half.
What kind of conditions, living conditions, did y'all have?
I mean, just describe your hoochies, you know, where you slept.
Did y'all have hot food or sea rats most of the time?
The conditions on this fire base was bad, real bad.
Of course, you lived in hoochies and you lived underground.
It was cold.
When it rained in the monsoon, it was damp, muddy.
Rats were so bad, you had to leave your boots on.
You had to sleep with your clothes on because the rats nibble you or eat at you.
They'd eat everything you had.
They tried to get us hot food up there once a week.
They tried.
They kept us supplied with water.
Everything came in by chopper.
And our water ration, they try to keep us enough water supply.
So we mainly ate sea rations.
As far as showers, we had a little shower stall.
and you punch holes in it, somebody would get a canister.
You was allowed three canisters of water.
When the water came in, you was allowed three.
And you'd get it, pour it through the hole, and that was your shower.
But if you didn't have any water, you didn't take a shower.
So the conditions up there on this fire base was bad, real bad.
Terribly bad.
Flies, mosquitoes, spiders, you name it.
It was bad.
Did the VC or the NVA bother y'all much on this fire base?
Were y'all under mortar attack constantly?
In the year and a half, there was a long fight.
Probably about three, four months was a long fight.
Usually that hit you with harassments, mortar rounds.
Usually if a helicopter came in, they'd hit you with a rocket fire.
They launched some ground attacks against us, but we weren't ever under siege as far as our fire base.
There came a time where the Tet Offensive came in where we were up countless days and nights firing, and also from the ground attacks, but that was probably, the Tet Offensive lasted about a month.
Most of it was mostly rocket and mortar round attacks.
Most of this come at night?
Yeah, the ground attacks came at night, but the mortar rounds and rocket rounds, they hit you in the daytime.
Did you ever get to go back to the rear during this year and a half?
You have a Saigon R&R.
How often did that happen?
So you got an R&R every six months where they ask you if you want to go to Taipei, Bangkok, Hawaii, the Philippines, Japan, whatever.
And I usually went to Taipei.
The girls are pretty there.
I mean, I guess in the rear what we most guys doing is okay in the rear and our rear was plate to that was the city.
And that was our main attachment.
That's where headquarters was.
And that was called artillery here.
It was in the city and the life back in the city was like living in Holland Park.
You went to the rear to play coup to headquarters battalion.
That was like living in Highland Park.
I mean, you had all the necessities you needed there.
You name it, you had it.
So that was like, man, just leaving the slums of East Dallas and going to Highland Park.
That was the difference.
All right.
Did the...
The Army trained you adequately to do your job in the field?
Well, the Army didn't train me to do my job.
I learned OJT.
My twin brother was trained in the artillery business, and he went to Fort Sill.
But I went from the south of Vietnam, and I was a radio operator down there for an engineer unit.
And I didn't see any combat.
I didn't see nothing down there.
So I wanted to be with my twin brother.
And I think even today, I think it's a rarity that my twin and I were together in a combat situation up in the Central Highlands.
And both of us came forward observers.
My job down there was very easy, and I was trained for that job.
But once I left there and went to the Central Highlands to be with my brother to be on these guns, I had zero training, zero.
And my only training to become an FO was when we was getting hit by mortar rounds.
And I was calling in support from another fire base to give us support because we was getting hit.
And after I got through with calling in these rounds,
My first sergeant said, hey, that's great.
You're going to be an FO.
And then he sent my brother and I to train to an FO school for one week.
And then when I came back up, I became an FO.
Let's get a more general scale.
Your staff NCOs, the majority of them, were they trained well enough to do their job?
Or was it more of a hurry up, let's get more people in here and see what they can do?
We're always at our NCOs.
I would feel, when I look back at it now, that's a question I wouldn't ask.
That's the first time I've been asked that.
I always say, looking back today, that they wouldn't train that well.
I don't think they were.
Because most of them lived in fear, and they wanted out.
They were out there in the field for six months, and that was it when they got out.
Officers and NCOs, and I'm saying E6 or E7 and above served six months in the field, and they were back out again.
So they didn't really care.
What about the officers?
The officers didn't play a very minor role because the men wouldn't listen to an officer.
They had no respect for an officer.
Okay.
Why was this?
Were the officers just not prepared or didn't care?
Yeah, the officers were what we refer to 90-day wonders.
They went to school and they learned something so quick inside of three months.
They came back out and they had to serve their six months in the field or the bush.
And then once they got out there, they was not prepared.
They was only prepared by the textbook of what they were taught in the books.
Once they got out there, things changed.
Things were different.
And they were ill-prepared for that because it didn't work.
It just didn't work.
The officers seemed more concerned about their careers, going to Vietnam, getting their ticket punched, advancing their career for later stages.
I can't really say that.
From the officers that I knew that came up, there was quite a few.
They just wanted to come up and serve their time and get the hell out.
So more or less, they just punched in and wanted out.
And that was it.
They didn't want to stay out in the field.
Was your unit a pretty close group up on this fire base?
High sense of camaraderie, high spirit?
Well, the fire base that we was on, fire base six, there was a total of, I would say, 40 to 50 men.
on this little fire base.
And we were divided.
You had your Blacks, your Whites, you had your Dopers, and the Alkies.
You had your Northerns, and you had your Southerns.
So it was very divided.
When everything was quiet, it was divided.
Let's discuss some of the different operations that you would go on.
If I could have you to describe an operation that you can remember that was a success.
A success would be one where I went out on a chopper and I had to replace an RTO, a radio operator, in Coppolaire and they had to extract him out of the jungle.
And of course, you know, before you went out to the jungle, you had to go back to headquarters and get briefed on what you had to do.
And they'd give you an SOP book and everything.
They gave you a map and everything else.
Now, they flew me out by this one, by this chopper, and they flew me in.
And they dropped me into it, and they was waiting on me.
And while we were there, it was all mountain yards.
And the leader of the group was a guy named King Groot.
He was a Green Beret.
They called him King Groot.
You know, they didn't have any names.
They had nicknames.
His name was Kangaroo.
The main objective of this bunch was to hit and run.
And I was there just long enough where I almost got picked to do the hit and run.
But I think the guy that was with me, the guy that, the FO, he told Kangaroo, he says, well, I'm a little bit too green.
I can't do this hit and run.
So at the last minute, he managed to pull me out of it.
So the basic objective of this group is to do a hit and run on an NVA unit that was around, and to kill as many as they could, and then we can get the hell out.
And that's what happened.
I went out, made a hit and run, and then for two days ran.
What about a failure in any particular incident that something just completely fell apart
That you remember?
Failure.
I can't think of a failure.
I really can't.
I can't think of a breakdown at all.
Okay.
Well, let's get into the situation here.
You're a Fort Observer calling an artillery fire.
Was this fire fairly accurate?
Uh, it all depended on the group that you had, you know.
I was up there on those guns and I knew that drugs were bad.
And if the guys came up there and they had a bad attitude, and there were always bad attitudes, there were drugs, you could get a round that would land right on top of him, you know.
You just didn't know.
You just hoped that you got the best group of guys on the right gun section.
you know, and hope that that group got it, and they caught it in the fire.
But there was some times where they caught it, boy, they dropped it right on top of it.
Right on top.
Let me close that door real quick.
All right.
I didn't sign 10.
Your unit was basically attached with ARVN units and mountain yards and some Korean soldiers.
What did you think of the South Vietnamese Army?
I was very dissatisfied with the South Vietnamese soldiers.
They didn't care.
Their morale was low.
It was ragtag.
They didn't care.
When you went out with them, they kind of went out like they just didn't care, like, you know,
go off through the bush, and if they see a trail, they'd follow the trail.
It didn't make any sense.
If you were with the mountain yards, it was a very strict discipline group.
They would make their own way, but the orange was a very poor discipline, low morale group.
Very poor.
So that base could have cared less whether they won the war or not?
That's exactly the feeling we got.
We knew it.
Do they just, I mean, one government under North Vietnamese rule or one government South Vietnamese rule?
Well, there's a lot of, you know, there's a lot of hatred between South Vietnamese soldiers and American soldiers when we was up there on this little fire base.
When the Vietnamese was on the perimeter, there was a lot of hatred.
A lot of hatred.
There were times where it came very close where we almost had firefights with them, right there on the hilltop.
So there was a lot of hatred.
There was no rapport or cooperation whatsoever.
The mountain yards that I've read were good fighters?
Excellent fighters.
Excellent.
What was their basic goals?
I mean, they would seem to be just a tribal unit within South Vietnam.
What were their goals in this war?
It's kind of hard to say because, you know, the Special Forces, or Mag V, trained them.
So what their objective was, what their goals were in that region is hard to say because I can't answer that.
I can't answer that.
But they were excellent soldiers.
Excellent.
Did the Koreans perform?
Yeah, the Koreans did.
They was a rock hard unit.
They did an excellent job.
They were very hard and very skilled.
Very good soldiers.
They fought very well.
Did you ever interact with the Vietnamese people much?
Yes.
What did they think about the war?

I think Vietnamese people look more at the war, not so much as the war, as they were caught up in the city dwelling and the city life as far as just getting the soldiers money, the economy, and all the money that came with it.
That's all they cared about.
They just reaped the profits.
Black market, yeah, you betcha, black market.
Whatever they could make a buck on, that's all they cared about.
Dad didn't care about the war he won or he lost, as long as they made the bucks off the GI.
That's all they cared about.
They just wanted to have rice on their table at night, enough food to eat.
Well, whatever they wanted the money for.
What did the South Vietnamese people think about the North Vietnamese?
or I guess there's really not that much of a distinction.
That was a distinction we gave everything.
What they thought about the communist regime in the North, in Ho Chi Minh.
Yeah.
Von, you know, you got to remember I was 18 years old.
18, 19 years old.
And I couldn't begin to comprehend that type of thinking.
I couldn't even begin to think.
So, you know, you asked me a question at the time I never thought of.
Okay.
All right.
Did you...
How much involvement, or did the North Vietnamese follow y'all that much at the time?
NVA units, or did y'all basically have VC?
We basically had VC in the area.
But the NVA would launch an offensive, mainly doing the Tet Offensive.
They'd launch an offensive.
And in our region,
They'd be very heavy doing the 10 offensive.
Very heavy in our region.
Extremely heavy.
But they never did bowler's in most of the VCs that bowler has.
The NVA good soldiers?
They were good fighters.
Intense.
Yeah, they were good.
Well trained, well armed.
And the VC were just...
in and out, never knew where they were?
Oh, they were in and out, but you know, their dedication is what carried them.
You know, that's what made the distinction between a South Vietnamese soldier who was well armed and well supposedly trained as a player to the VC.
You know, they were just a ragtag farmer during the day and a soldier at night, you know, was their dedication, what they believed in.
And that was a difference out there.
So that made the B.C.
a well-trained individual for what he believed in.
Before we started this interview on tape, I was asked some questions about and brought up anti-war demonstrators.
Could you tell me your feelings about these people on tape?
I dislike them.
I hate them.
I have a lot of hatred for him even today.
I can't find one today that admit that he was a demonstrator.
To me they're just chickens.
They just backed out.
They're scared.
They're scared now to admit what they were now.
And that just goes to show you what they was afraid of back then.
They're just a lot of bunch of chickens, all they are.
They didn't have enough guts, enough pride, nothing to stand up what they believed in.
And at least if they didn't believe in it, just stand behind their government.
And I hate them.
I hate them.
During your tour in Vietnam, did you feel that you were doing the right thing?
Yes.
With Vietnamese people?
Well, I didn't look at it like that.
I felt like it was the right thing to serve my country.
That's what I looked at.
The utmost was I'm serving my country.
That's what I'm looking at.
I never thought about going over there and protecting the South of Vietnam.
Never once crossed my mind.
My utmost was I'm serving my country.
If my country wants me to go, I'm going to go.
That's what my sole purpose was.
All right.
What did you feel about the draft?
The draft?
Well, of course, I volunteered for the draft.
I was going to get in, serve my two years, and get out.
The draft I felt like was right.
I wish I had the draft today.
It would help.
the younger people understand a lot more about responsibility, dedication about life in general.
It teaches you a lot.
I mean, it's helped me in my life now at the age of almost 40 years old in what I've learned when I was in the Army and been drafted.
And what I learned at that age that I can apply to my life now.
And then when times are tough, times are hard, I can always look back at what I did in Vietnam where things hurt.
Extremely tough and related to today, and it helped me through a lot of problems.
It helped me through a lot.
Okay.
What about the people who joined the National Guard at this time to get out?
Was that... What, back then?
Back then.
I never knew about it.
I really didn't.
You know, being 18 years old, the only thing I had in my mind was just going in.
Okay.
Very good.
This war was the first, quote, TV war.
Mass media in Vietnam brought the war home the next night to the American public.
Was the press and the media involved where you were, or did you ever see them?
The only press we had out there I remember was Stars and Stripes.
You know, they came up to the fire base and did a story.
But they was mainly up there to do a story of my brother and I.
So did you know about the media or any problems that it was causing elsewhere?
Reporters being in?
No, because we never got papers.
Where we was at, the only kind of communication we had was armed forces radio.
If you're lucky to have a radio, then that's what you heard on the news.
But you never got a newspaper telling you what's going on.
Never.
I'd like to dig into some of the problems that were prevalent during this time.
Drugs were a big problem.
Could you elaborate a little bit?
Drugs was terrible.
Drugs was so bad.
I think that was the big cause of our...
As far as our involvement in Vietnam, in the way that everybody's attitude was, you know, the way they looked at the war was drugs.
I mean, it tore a lot of men up.
It tore a lot of young men up.
They lost a lot of lives, too, on the count of drugs.
Was it just a lack of education about drugs, what they could do, or why did the men turn to it?
Well, I'm sure it's lack of education because nobody knew about drugs.
I didn't know what a marijuana cigarette was until I went over there.
I had no idea what a marijuana cigarette was.
I didn't know what a marijuana cigarette was until I was on the way up to the Central Highlands to meet my brother and I got on this helicopter
with this other guy from California.
And we was going back, and the fire base was getting attacked at the time.
So they had to drop us off at this other area.
This one guy had a marijuana cigarette and said, hey, you want to try this?
And of course, I was John Wayne out of the American flag.
I said, yeah, I'll try.
So that's my first time I ever knew about drugs.
So there was a lack of education.
Nobody knew about it, how to approach it, how to defend it.
So drugs are just so rampant.
You've been 18, 19, 20-year-olds.
They didn't know how to cope with it.
Okay.
Was marijuana the main drug that was being used, or was there others?
Well, it's hard to say.
I say all of it was, yeah, all of it, you know.
Marijuana was easy to get to, but all of it was so easy to get to.
Yeah, so easy.
Was there a period during the war where drug use made a drastic, or the use of drugs increased a significant amount, or could you tell?
Yes.
I would say it did because it went from marijuana to the hard stuff.
Soon it was opium.
Soon all your marijuana was dusted with opium and things like that.
So it progressed later on.
Sure, eventually.
Sometime around after Tet, you notice the problems increasing or?
Yeah, the drugs were bad then because Tet put so much pressure and there was so much tension and stress on you.
And sometimes you went two, three, four days without sleep.
Yeah, drugs were real bad then.
Everybody would do uppers, they'd do anything to speed themselves up to get them going and things like that because you couldn't sleep.
Discipline was another problem.
And you've told me before that the men didn't listen to the officers.
Do you think there should have been a stronger discipline during this time if we could have performed better with stricter discipline in the field?
Well, they tried that, and it didn't work.
The only thing they got was the fact that the officers wanted to kill the soldiers.
The GIs wanted to kill the officers because if they came up there and tried to do this very strict discipline, like on a fire support base where we was at, everything's so lax.
You didn't worry about haircuts.
You didn't worry about baths.
You didn't worry about your boots.
You didn't care about nothing.
And then when there was a low on the fighting, and this is an example where we got this one captain up there named Captain Fink.
I never will forget his name.
And he came up and tried that and brought up all the shoe polish and ordered everybody to polish their boots.
Because that was the first sign of having discipline on this fire support base.
Well, it didn't work.
Everybody got their shoe polish and threw it over the perimeter of the barbed wires.
Threw it.
That night they tried to kill him.
That next day, he was out.
So it didn't work.
Was fragging a big problem?
Yeah.
They tried to kill them.
If they didn't like them, they tried to kill them.
All right.
The problem with the officers, let's say, what would you look for in an officer that would come up to your fire support base?
That the officer didn't come up and try to push everything down our throat.
That everybody wouldn't be left alone.
If there was a fire mission that had to be taken care of, then everybody got up there and did their job.
But they didn't want to be pushed around and made to do things like they did in the rear or the main base camp or headquarters battalion and how they were treated.
We didn't want to be treated the same way.
We wanted to be treated separate from all those people because we felt like we was out there.
We was doing it.
And we want to be left alone.
Job called, forced to do our job, we'd get up and do it.
But don't mess with nobody.
Just leave us alone.
And that was added to.
Thank you.
You mentioned earlier that there was different groups.
When things were lax, that the blacks would segregate off.
You'd have the northerners, the southerners, the whites, the druggies, and the alcoholics.
Was there a bad problem with the racism, I mean pure hatred, amongst the whites and blacks?
Up there on the fire base there wasn't.
You know, we just knew where they were coming from and they knew where we was coming from, but there was no bad hatred among us.
But you could tell that they're, you know, you leave us alone, we'll leave you alone.
And that was the type of attitude.
But still, when it came to working together, it all worked well.
It was all mixed well, but once everything was over, then everybody crawled back in a little hole, and that's the way it was.
Man, you left each other alone.
You didn't bother each other.
Is that the same basic sentiment in the rear also?
Yeah.
Where it's getting worse.
Yeah.
Yeah, in the rear, I would say that racism was worse in the rear because, you know, they...
The things that they had to go through back there was just like stateside duty.
So racism was definitely worse in the rear than it was in the field because you knew that you had to depend on each other out there in the field.
Where back there they didn't.
All right.
Did you feel that the potential of the American Army was being held back?
Because y'all felt y'all could have done more.
We could have kicked their ass easy, pure and simple.
We could have kicked their ass.
Man, we could have ran them out all the way out of Vietnam, north and south, easy, you betcha.
And that was part of it, too.
Everybody knew that we could have gone out there and kicked everybody's ass.
They came into it.
We could have kicked them off, but they wouldn't let us do it.
We had certain restrictions.
You couldn't fire too far this way.
You couldn't fire too far this way, but you could fire this way.
So there were so many restrictions where everybody just said, the hell with you.
But we could have kicked them all the way out, man.
There ain't no doubt in my mind.
And any Vietnam veteran would tell you that.
I thought it was the rules of this particular war that seemed to hold us back.
Right, it was rules.
Rules are set, and you couldn't break them.
Every now and then they were broke, but you had to hide it from the American public in order to break that rule.
If I could get back into the press and the American public seeing this back at home, what we were doing.
Right, it was bad PR.
I mean, this was war.
It was war.
I don't see where you can have this.
That's right.
That's why, Satan, you just said that.
It's hard to believe, but we thought the same thing.
Why can we have rules?
Why are there rules?
So everybody, of course, you don't get an answer.
You just do what you're supposed to do.
Okay.
You think we could have won this war?
Ain't no doubt in my mind.
Like I just said just a minute ago, we could have kicked them all the way out.
We could have kicked them all the way out.
What would you have done different?
What I could have done different?
On a whole, if you were looking at the war yourself... Oh, war.
And what, from your experiences...
Basically, when you go into a war, you declare it as a war, you go in and you kick your butts.
You have an objective, you go in with that objective, you conquer that objective, and you've done your job.
That's what I see about it.
If they would come up tomorrow and say, all Vietnam veterans, you can come back to South Vietnam,
And you can get over there and kick their butts any way you want to, in any direction, have at it.
Maybe we'd load up and we'd kick their ass.
So you'd go back and drop a hat?
I'd go back, damn right I would.
When you came home, what was American sentiment towards you?
Were you treated bad?
Well,
As soon as you came home, the first thing they did to you on the airplane was they stuck you off on the end of a runway.
And you had to sit there for three hours at the end of the runway.
They never explained to you why.
And you just sit there, you sat there for three hours, you couldn't understand, why are we just sitting here for three hours?
Well, once they get you off the airplane, they bring you into the reception center, and I'm talking about Fort Lewis, Washington.
They set you down in a room, and they, and they talk to you, and they, what, deprogram, or
I forgot what the terminology was for what they did to you.
But they deep programmed you, so to speak.
And all you want to do is just get in and get out.
Well, they did that for about an hour.
And then inside of another hour and a half, two hours, they give you a T-bone steak if you wanted it.
And then your airplane takes you back home.
Once you got to the airport, the sentiments were so bad and negative that it
There at the bar, I remember this one bar where I came in, the first thing I did was order me a drink.
I turned to this guy, I said, man, I'm just back home from Nam, and he looked at me and said, so what?
So, you know, that was my first impression coming back.
And I remember when I was going to Vietnam, I was going to Fort Lewis, Washington, to go to Vietnam, and I was on this airplane.
And the stewardess wouldn't even serve me.
She wouldn't serve me food because I was going to Vietnam.
And so the stewardess came back, or came up and asked me if I was hungry.
I said, yes, I am.
She said, well, I came in to get your food.
I said, well, she didn't ask me.
She says, OK. She said, she does this to Vietnam veterans.
She won't serve a Vietnam veteran.
So that's what you had to encounter.
John, you stated that
You moved from the engineering battalion up to Central Highlands to be your brother.
How did this come about?
How did you get to go up there?
Well, it's kind of funny.
I've got to go back just a little bit more because my brother went in the service corps I did.
And I went in approximately five, six months after he did.
And they shipped him straight to Vietnam from artillery school.
But when I went in, they sent me to Germany.
Well, while in Germany, I re-enlisted three years in the Army to go to Vietnam.
So when I came home, they sent me to Vietnam to the Mekong Delta, and they shipped my twin brother from Vietnam to Germany.
So I was in a non-combat role in South Vietnam in the Delta.
And my brother was in Germany at the time.
Well, he re-enlisted three more years to go back to Vietnam.
So he went back to Vietnam, and they sent him up to the Central Highlands.
Well, the time that I was down at the Delta, I was very unhappy.
I wanted to play a role in combat.
I mean, I wanted to be out there in the bush.
I mean, I wanted to beat the bush, and I wanted to be out there.
And I had a couple friends in school that died that were killed in Vietnam.
So I wanted to go to Vietnam, and I wanted to fight in Vietnam.

I tried to get out of this engineer unit to be with my brother, and I went to the inspector general, I went to the chaplain, I went through all the channels that you could possibly go through to get out.
And it was always revoked by this Captain Sears, which I won't forget his name, because he didn't want me to go, because it looked bad on him if a man transferred out of your unit.
It looked bad.
Well,
All the channels that I went through fell.
And I was at a bar one night, and I was talking to this black GI.
He was an E6 in personnel.
And we was talking, and I was talking about my dilemma, why I was down.
And he said, listen, man, I'm in personnel.
I'll help you get out.
Now, this is another sign of how the Army works, you know.
And an E6, this guy got me out inside of three days.
Got the paperwork, got it approved, and everything.
Got me out in three days, and I went up to Central Highlands with my brother, where we was up there together.
As far as I know, I think we're the only 20 that was together in Vietnam.
Did y'all go on operations together?
No, we always went separate.
Always went separate.
Yeah, right.
The first sergeant insisted that we went separate.
Of course, we agreed to go separate.
We never went on the same one.
All right, well, John, I appreciate it.
Okay.
I hope your answers and everything can help some other people understand kind of what went on.
I'd like to give a little brief summary here that I'd like to say thank you very much for asking these questions.

This is the first time that I've ever been asked questions of this sort, and it feels good to be asked these questions, and I hope that in some way that my answers can help the younger people that are going to come up
in your day and behind you that can help understand what we went through.
There's a lot more that you just can't express in 45 minutes.
There's a lot more that needs to be said to the people to let them know what we went through.
But I do want to say thank you very much for coming up here and asking me these questions.
It feels very good, and I want to thank you very much.
Appreciate it, John.
Thank you.
Thank you.
